common

In more complex app which have auth and you need interceptor http client is the best to go.

However, for example, if you are creating simple app, like you show in youtube channel or docs, the fetch API would be enough.

This should not be in core / common module because you may not use and be in separete npm module like router.

### Proposed solution

- make http client as separated package, at least for new App
-  not be installed by default 
- may be ask when install new App
- command to install it after create new app

With this change will improve installation and setup time.

And best way when you want to start with the most simple way, to just test simple things or create simple apps.

Of course if later on , the user change their mind, should exist a command to install and setup the this modules.

Issues.Title: Hydration: add a warning when ApplicationRef.isStable doesn't emit `true` after some time
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

Currently, Angular hydration logic depends on the `ApplicationRef.isStable` on the client for a couple things:

- when the post-hydration DOM cleanup should happen (to remove all unclaimed DOM segments)
- when to output hydration stats into a console
- when the HttpClient cache should no longer be in use

We've received a few requests where hydration stats are not displayed in a console after hydration and in all cases this leads into `ApplicationRef.isStable` not emitting `true`. There are various reasons for this and in in vast majority of cases the problems are **unrelated** to hydration. However, previously this was not "visible" in the app, but with hydration the use of `ApplicationRef.isStable` increased and it becomes more important to get to the "stable" state.

As a first step to improve the DX, we should add a warning when the app didn't get to the "stable" state after some time (N seconds, N=10?). For this warning it'd be also important to have an error guide page to explain this problem in more details and provide some hints on how to resolve that. We could also use this error guide page to collect more information about use-cases over time.

Relevant code: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/hydration/api.ts#L162-L183.

Issues.Title: Sass files not correctly compiled with new ESBuild
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler-cli

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

When Angular now compiles with the ESBuild option (using Angular 16), sass files no longer import external resources (using the `url`) correctly.
Essentially, behavior is such that if a Sass file (let's call it module A) imports another sass file (let's call it module B), and module B lives in a different directory than Module A, and Module B uses a url to point to a relative file (like a font file), when Sass compiles everything into a single Sass file, the url that's used from Module B remains the same (which is relative to the original Module B location), resulting in errors around resolving file locations (because the compiled file doesn't have the same file location as the original).
Original behavior didn't care about this, and the compiled output correctly brought linked files up and changed the url paths.
While ESBuild is called a "drop-in" replacement, this needs to be resolved.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support incremental TypeScript semantic diagnostics in esbuild builder
Issues.Body:
When using the esbuild-based browser application builder with CLI caching enabled, TypeScript's `incremental`
option will also be enabled by default. A TypeScript build information file will be written after each build and
an attempt to load and use the file will be made during compilation setup. Caching is enabled by default within
the CLI and can be controlled via the `ng cache` command. This is the first use of persistent caching for the
esbuild-based builder. If the TypeScript `incremental` option is manually set to `false`, the build system will
not alter the value. This can be used to disable the behavior, if preferred, by setting the option to `false` in
the application's configured `tsconfig` file.
NOTE: The build information only contains information regarding the TypeScript compilation itself and does not
contain information about the Angular AOT compilation. TypeScript does not have knowledge of the AOT compiler
and it therefore cannot include that information in its build information file. Angular AOT analysis is still
performed for each build.

Initial profiling indicates this provides a ~20% improvement to warm build times for a production build of a newly generated project.

```ts
}

minSliderValueChange(value: number, index: number) {
  // ...
}

// ...
```

However, in the newly released v16.0.0, this behavior appears to have changed. The `valueChange` event only emits a value when the slider dragging operation ends, as opposed to continuously during the drag.

To restore the previous behavior, one workaround I found is using `ngModel` for template-driven binding:
```html
<mat-slider>
  <input
    [(ngModel)]="sliderValue"
    (ngModelChange)="sliderValueChange($event)"
    matSliderThumb
  />
</mat-slider>
```

Alternatively, I achieved the same result by using `formControl` with reactive forms and subscribing to `valueChange`:
```html
<mat-slider>
  <input
    (dragStart)="dragSliderStartMin(index)"
    [formControl]="expectationMin($event, index)"
    matSliderStartThumb
  />
  <input
    (dragStart)="dragSliderStartMax(index)"
    [formControl]="expectationMax($event, index)"
    matSliderEndThumb
  />
</mat-slider>
```
```ts

ngOnInit() {
  this.addSubscriptions();
}

addSubscriptions() {
  this.expectationMin(this.index)
    .valueChanges.pipe(distinctUntilChanged())
    .subscribe((value) => {
      console.log('min value changed', value);
      this.minSliderValueChange(value, this.index);
    });

  // same for expectationMax and maxSliderValueChange
}
```

I wanted to bring up this change in behavior as it may impact other users who relied on the continuous value emission during slider drags in their projects. Can anyone confirm if this change was intentional or if it's a bug?

### Reproduction

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Reproduction of the issue in Angular v16.0.0

Navigate to the StackBlitz sample code for Angular v16.0.0: [Angular 16 slider with valueChanges showing value only when drag ends](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-16-material-starter-xdmmkz?file=package.json).

In this sample, notice that when you drag the slider, the value changes are only displayed when the dragging ends. This is the behavior we're discussing in this issue.

2. Comparison with the behavior in Angular v15.1.0

Now, navigate to the StackBlitz sample code for Angular v15.1.0: [Angular 15, same source code, slider with valueChanges showing value when dragging the slider](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-16-material-starter-fmmekv?file=package.json).

In this sample, when you drag the slider, the value changes are continuously displayed next to the slider as you're dragging. This is the previous behavior we're comparing to.

By observing the behavior in both versions of Angular with the same source code, you can clearly see the difference in valueChange event emissions during slider dragging.

### Expected Behavior

In Angular Material version 15.1.0, the `valueChange` event used with `matSliderThumb` was designed to emit values continuously as the slider was being dragged. This enabled real-time value updates during a drag operation. I expect to see this same behavior in Angular Material version 16.0.0.

### Actual Behavior

In Angular Material version 16.0.0, the `valueChange` event's behavior appears to have changed. Instead of emitting values continuously during the slider dragging operation, it now only emits a value when the slider drag operation ends. This change interrupts real-time value updates and only allows for updates when the user releases the slider.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.0.0
- CDK/Material: 16.0.0
- Browser(s): Version 113.0.5672.92 (Official Build) (arm64)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs Ventura, Version 13.3.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`valueChange` Event in v16.0.0 No Longer Emits Values Continuously During Slider Drag" (#27097)

Issues.Title: bug(DateAdapter): `MAT_DATE_LOCALE` injection-type doesn't support most commonly used `string`
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

_(minor bug; and casting `as string` workaround present)_

In Angular 13 ([release tag 13.0.0-next.0](https://github.com/angular/components/releases/tag/13.0.0-next.0)) date-fns support was added to the DateAdapter. 
Overall a great change, but today I encountered an issue with the `MAT_DATE_LOCALE` being type `InjectionToken<{}>` instead of the previous `InjectionToken<string>`, which was changed when the date-fns support was added.

The minor issue occurs when I try to use the Angular 14's `inject(...)` function call instead of constructor DI-injection, where our previous `@Optional() @Inject(MAT_DATE_LOCALE) dateLocale: string | null` constructor argument cannot be changed to `private readonly dateLocale: string | null = inject(MAT_DATE_LOCALE, {optional: true});` without an additional `as string` cast.

In the pull-request (https://github.com/angular/components/pull/23262), I do see the following two comments mentioning it had been discussed the Monday prior, but I'm curious what has been discussed in that case?

https://github.com/angular/components/pull/23262#pullrequestreview-717428750
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/5364335/0f0569a3-6f31-4d0c-96f7-de641ceff810)

### Reproduction

Step to reproduce:
- Add `private readonly dateLocale: string | null = inject(MAT_DATE_LOCALE, {optional: true});` to any Angular TS file (preferably a DateAdapter, but doesn't matter too much for the reproduction scenario).

### Expected Behavior

`string` should be one of the allowed types of `inject(MAT_DATE_LOCALE)`. Especially since you're using `MAT_DATE_LOCALE_FACTORY()` -> `inject(LOCALE_ID)`, which is of type `InjectionToken<string>`, and [in your own datepicker example page](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/219c6d0874e568fe55f30bb5538cb4f1c724a836/src/components-examples/material/datepicker/index.ts#L113) you're also using a `string` as `useValue`.

### Actual Behavior

I'm getting the `TS2322: Type '{} | null' is not assignable to type 'string | null'.` error, unless I add an `as string` cast.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.0.0
- CDK/Material: 16.0.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(DateAdapter): `MAT_DATE_LOCALE` injection-type doesn't support most commonly used `string`" (#27087)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-checkbox): checkbox is not affected by theme default density
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2.7

### Description

I am currently migrating from v14 to v15 and i'm now trying to rework my layouts to match the previous v14 look as much as possible.

I have always been using a custom theme and i am importing the component themes on my own (NOT using the `all-component-themes`).

Since everything was a bit smaller in v14 i tried to mimic this by relying on the new density-features. When playing around with v15 and density i have noticed that some components seem to not care about the default density defined in my theme.

A very obvious one is the checkbox which does not care about the default density at all.

There are two checkboxes, a default one and an explicitly denser one. In the theme.scss i have set the default theme density to 0.

A "denser checkbox" is wrapped in a div with css-class "dense", which is used in theme.scss to include the checkbox-density(-3) explicity.

Given i change the theme default density to -3, i expect the default checkbox to shrink to the same size of the explicitly denser checkbox. However the default checkbox stays the same size, ignoring the default density.

A simple form-field/input however proves that the theme is configured properly, since the input will shrink based on the provided theme default density.

### Reproduction

See a minimal reproduction on [stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-autocomplete-density-issue-pzrcpe?file=src/theme.scss)

### Expected Behavior

I expect the checkbox to respect the theme density and shrink accordingly.

### Actual Behavior

The checkbox stays the same size no matter what the theme density is.

### Environment

- Angular: 15.2.8
- CDK/Material: 15.2.8
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Linux
